qas.question: What occurred to the level of the sea when the Devonian period was finished?
During which period were epicontinental seas created?
What was on the land at 30 degrees latitude north in the carboniferous period?
What was the result in the decline in sea level in the middle of the Carboniferous period?
The Pennsylvania period is separated by the drop in Carboniferous era sea levels from what other period?
What dropped world wide at the begining of the Devonian?
How widespread was the drop in sea llevel in the Carboniferous?
What temperatures dropped during the Devonian?
What region was deeply impacted by the conditions of the Carboniferous?
What could be found just north of the glacerers

context: <a0_0>A <b6_0>global<b6_0/> drop<a0_0/> in <b5_0>sea level<b5_0/> at the end of the Devonian reversed early in the <a1_0>Carboniferous<a1_0/>; this created the widespread epicontinental seas and carbonate deposition of the Mississippian. There was also a drop in <b7_0>south polar<b7_0/> temperatures; southern Gondwana was glaciated throughout the period, though it is uncertain if the ice sheets were a holdover from the Devonian or not. These conditions apparently had little effect in the <b8_0>deep tropics<b8_0/>, where <a2_0><b9_0>lush coal swamps<b9_0/><a2_0/> flourished within 30 degrees of the northernmost glaciers. A mid-Carboniferous drop in sea-level precipitated <a3_0>a major marine extinction<a3_0/>, one that hit crinoids and ammonites especially hard. This sea-level drop and the associated unconformity in North America separate the <a4_0>Mississippian Period<a4_0/> from the Pennsylvanian period.
